content.description: Fun obscure route. Starts with with flat edges and an arete, a tricky crux above the 2nd bolt, and big drilled holds to the finish. History unknown, grade is purely speculation.
content.protection: 3 bolts to anchors. Clean your anchor draws from the rim.
content.location: 100 feet downstream of the falls on the tallest part of the cliff

content.description: The crux comes in the first 15 feet. Fiddle some small gear and pull through a bulge on a few finger locks and face holds. The difficulty eases in the second half.
content.protection: Small cams to #.75, maybe a few small nuts. Two bolt anchor, you can access from the rim to clean your gear or establish a TR. A tree 20 feet back provides an anchor if needed.

content.description: Start in a wide corner and follow a right-leaning crack with good rests and solid gear. After a few moves, stem back into the corner and top out. Tree belay.
content.location: Big ninety degree corner on a little hill.

content.description: Double cracks past some solid wedged blocks to a right-facing corner and a dirty top out. Tree belay 15 feet back from the rim, 30 second walk off.
content.protection: Finger size gear and a very short rope
content.location: About 100 yards downstream of the falls, near the standard approach gully.

content.description: Short, steep corner crack. Boulder off the ground past some slippery paint. Stemming and tips laybacks lead around a roof to the finish. Feels a little harder than Wartley's?
content.protection: Double set of cams from tips to BD #.75. Two bolt anchor. May be more practical to lead rather than drop a TR from the above, due to the steep leaning nature and the 10 foot boulder behind your back.
content.location: Right of the sport route, by the gnarly narwhal petrograph.

content.description: Zig-zag finger crack to corner. Tree belay, easy walk off.
content.location: About 100 yards downstream of the falls on the east side of the river, near the approach gully. Directly right of End of the World Party

content.description:
Begin scrambling up a grassy ledge, then either jam or use small face holds to establish yourself in the tight dihedral.  Use more shenanigans to move up over the slight overhang and mantle to the anchor.  I can't justify calling it 5.10a due to only having one or two tricky moves, but it is certainly more awkward and strenuous than your run of the mill 5.9.  

 You can set up a TR from a tree back from the edge a few feet, or do the exposed one move downclimb to the ledge where the anchor is.  I wouldn't recommend the latter without a rappel/belay of some sort.
content.protection: Cams in the .4-.75 BD range.  2 bolt anchor.  Top out to clean gear from anchor.
content.location: Walk downstream maybe 50 yards from the bolted prow and look for an arching, tight dihedral.

content.description: West-facing basalt cliff downstream of the waterfall. The wall is several hundred feet long and includes short routes up to 40 feet tall, highball boulders and lowball traverses. Fairly easy top rope access to most things by trees near the rim. There's potential for a few more short, traditional grit-style lines on the wall with a bit of cleaning.
